India Gate is an important monument located in Delhi, India. It was built in memory of Indian soldiers who lost their lives fighting for the British Army during World War I. The construction of the monument began in 1921 and was completed in 1931. The monument is made of sandstone and stands at a height of 42 meters. It has a central arch with a diameter of 9.1 meters, which is inscribed with the names of 13,218 soldiers. 

 Every year, on Republic Day, a parade is held at India Gate to celebrate the country's freedom. There is also an eternal flame or Amar Jawan Jyoti, which symbolizes the flame of the immortal soldier. The flame at the center of the monument represents the spirit of these soldiers, which will never die. The Amar Jawan Jyoti was built in 1971 after the Indo-Pakistani War and is a constant reminder of the sacrifices made by soldiers in protecting their country. 

 India Gate reminds us of the bravery and sacrifice of the soldiers who fought for the freedom of their country.
